description:
This protocol describes how to use a short-term cold shock to render Aiptasia aposymbiotic.

After the cold shock it includes two possibilities to proceed one faster one with usage of DCMU and a slower and more gentle one with only keeping the animals in the dark.
before_start:
Fluorescence filters:

Every wavelength between 400 and 550 nm efficiently axcites the algal chlorophyll.

The chlorophyll fluorescence emission peaks between 650 and 720 nm.

This means that most RFP filter sets with a wide bandpass or longpass emission filter at above 600 nm will work well.

GFP longpass filter sets will work as well but only in combination with an RGB camera to distinguish red algal fluorescence and green autofluorescence of the anemones themselves.

These numbers are only rough estimations based on a few algal strains. For purchasing new filter sets it will be still best to test them before buying.
warning:
DCMU is toxic and suspected to be carcinogenic.

https://chemicalsafety.com/sds1/sdsviewer.php?id=30234487&name=3-(3%2C4-Dichlorophenyl)-1%2C1-dimethylurea
keywords: Aiptasia, Symbiodinium, cold shock, aposymbiotic, bleaching, DCMU

collections.protocol_name: Getting started with the Aiptasia-Symbiodinium Model System
collections.protocol_name_html: Getting started with the Aiptasia-Symbiodinium Model System

guidelines:
Preparing DCMU (3-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)-1,1-dimethylurea) stock solution:

0.0313 M DCMU in 95-100% ethanol.

For 50 ml, dissolve 7.3 mg in 50 ml ethanol.

 

For an end concentration of 50 µM add 32 µl of the stock to 200 ml of artificial seawater.

components.data:
Prepare a tank of anemones.

It is best (but not critical) if you let them sit in the tank until they stick to the sides/bottom of the tank.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Prepare a tank of anemones.

It is best (but not critical) if you let them sit in the tank until they stick to the sides/bottom of the tank.

components.data: Chill a large volume of seawater to 4°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Chill a large volume of seawater to 4°C.

components.data: Pour out the seawater in the Aiptasia tank and replace it with the 4°C seawater. Place the entire tank into a 4°C refrigerator (or cold room).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pour out the seawater in the Aiptasia tank and replace it with the 4°C seawater. Place the entire tank into a 4°C refrigerator (or cold room).

components.data:
Remove the tank from 4°C, pour out the cold water, and replace with room-temperature seawater.

The animals will be spitting out boluses of algae, which you will see as dark brown balls next to the anemones
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Remove the tank from 4°C, pour out the cold water, and replace with room-temperature seawater.

The animals will be spitting out boluses of algae, which you will see as dark brown balls next to the anemones

components.data: Repeat the water change 2-3 times by pouring out the tank water and replacing it with room-temperature seawater.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Repeat the water change 2-3 times by pouring out the tank water and replacing it with room-temperature seawater.

components.data: Place the tank into darkness (we use dark cabinets) at room temperature for 1 – 2 days. Continue to replace seawater with room-temperature seawater once a day.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the tank into darkness (we use dark cabinets) at room temperature for 1 – 2 days. Continue to replace seawater with room-temperature seawater once a day.

components.data: You now have two options: a faster method or a slower method. The faster method works quickly but is harsher on the anemones; the slower method is more gentle on the anemones but takes longer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: You now have two options: a faster method or a slower method. The faster method works quickly but is harsher on the anemones; the slower method is more gentle on the anemones but takes longer.

cases.title: Fast and harsh bleaching
cases.label: Using DCMU to remove algae faster but with more stress to the animals

cases.title: Slower and more gentle bleaching
cases.label: Keeping the anemones in darkness until they are aposymbiotic

components.data:
Prepare seawater containing DCMU (or ‘diuron’: 3-[3,4-dichlorophenyl]-1,1-dimethylurea). We generally use a final DCMU concentration in seawater between 10 μM and 50 μM.

Higher concentrations work faster, but are harsher on the anemones so you may need more frequent water changes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Prepare seawater containing DCMU (or ‘diuron’: 3-[3,4-dichlorophenyl]-1,1-dimethylurea). We generally use a final DCMU concentration in seawater between 10 μM and 50 μM.

Higher concentrations work faster, but are harsher on the anemones so you may need more frequent water changes.

components.data: Leave tank in complete darkness with regular room-temperature seawater. Continue to change the water every 1 – 2 days. Feed animals at least once a week, but 2 – 3 times a week if possible: whenever you feed, change the water the next day.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Leave tank in complete darkness with regular room-temperature seawater. Continue to change the water every 1 – 2 days. Feed animals at least once a week, but 2 – 3 times a week if possible: whenever you feed, change the water the next day.

components.data: Remove the tank from the dark cabinet. Replace tank seawater with the DCMU-seawater. Incubate at room temperature in constant light for several weeks.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove the tank from the dark cabinet. Replace tank seawater with the DCMU-seawater. Incubate at room temperature in constant light for several weeks.

components.data:
Replace the water with DCMU-seawater once or twice a week (depending on how the anemones look: when they appear very unhappy, replace the water). Feed anemones with brine shrimp at least once a week; more feeding is better, so feed 2 – 3 times a week if possible.

Importantly, after each feeding the water must be changed the next day.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Replace the water with DCMU-seawater once or twice a week (depending on how the anemones look: when they appear very unhappy, replace the water). Feed anemones with brine shrimp at least once a week; more feeding is better, so feed 2 – 3 times a week if possible.

Importantly, after each feeding the water must be changed the next day.

components.data:
You can start screening the anemones under a fluorescence stereoscope after 2 – 3 weeks to check for the presence of algae. Continue incubating with DCMU until anemones appear aposymbiotic.

See guidelines section for information about fluorescence filters.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
You can start screening the anemones under a fluorescence stereoscope after 2 – 3 weeks to check for the presence of algae. Continue incubating with DCMU until anemones appear aposymbiotic.

See guidelines section for information about fluorescence filters.

components.data:
When anemones appear aposymbiotic, incubate first a few of them in room-temperature seawater in the light (without DCMU) for 1 week and then check for algal presence under a fluorescence stereoscope.

Tthis step ensures there are no algae still in the anemones: if any are present, they will populate quickly over the week and become detectable.

If they still contain algae, continue the DCMU treatment. If they remain free of algae, they are fully aposymbiotic.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
When anemones appear aposymbiotic, incubate first a few of them in room-temperature seawater in the light (without DCMU) for 1 week and then check for algal presence under a fluorescence stereoscope.

Tthis step ensures there are no algae still in the anemones: if any are present, they will populate quickly over the week and become detectable.

If they still contain algae, continue the DCMU treatment. If they remain free of algae, they are fully aposymbiotic.

components.data: You can start screening the anemones under a fluorescence stereoscope after 1.5 months to check for the presence of algae. Continue incubating in the dark until anemones appear aposymbiotic.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: You can start screening the anemones under a fluorescence stereoscope after 1.5 months to check for the presence of algae. Continue incubating in the dark until anemones appear aposymbiotic.

components.data:
When anemones appear aposymbiotic, incubate first a few of them in room-temperature seawater in the light for 1 week and then check for algal presence under a fluorescence stereoscope.

This step ensures there are no algae still in the anemones: if any are present, they will populate quickly over the week and become detectable.

If they still contain algae, continue the dark treatment. If they remain free of algae, they are fully aposymbiotic.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
When anemones appear aposymbiotic, incubate first a few of them in room-temperature seawater in the light for 1 week and then check for algal presence under a fluorescence stereoscope.

This step ensures there are no algae still in the anemones: if any are present, they will populate quickly over the week and become detectable.

If they still contain algae, continue the dark treatment. If they remain free of algae, they are fully aposymbiotic.
